trans-unit.source: Buttons
trans-unit.target: Buttons

trans-unit.source: A button gives the user a way to trigger an immediate action.
trans-unit.target: A button gives the user a way to trigger an immediate action.

trans-unit.source: Example of buttons
trans-unit.target: Example of buttons

trans-unit.source: Important APIs
trans-unit.target: Important APIs

trans-unit.source: Button class
trans-unit.target: Button class

trans-unit.source: RepeatButton class
trans-unit.target: RepeatButton class

trans-unit.source: Click event
trans-unit.target: Click event

trans-unit.source: Is this the right control?
trans-unit.target: Is this the right control?

trans-unit.source: A button lets the user initiate an immediate action, such as submitting a form.
trans-unit.target: A button lets the user initiate an immediate action, such as submitting a form.

trans-unit.source: Don't use a button when the action is to navigate to another page; use a link instead.
trans-unit.target: Don't use a button when the action is to navigate to another page; use a link instead.

trans-unit.source: See [Hyperlinks](hyperlinks.md) for more info.
trans-unit.target: See [Hyperlinks](hyperlinks.md) for more info.

trans-unit.source: Exception: For wizard navigation, use buttons labeled "Back" and "Next".
trans-unit.target: Exception: For wizard navigation, use buttons labeled "Back" and "Next".

trans-unit.source: For other types of backwards navigation or navigation to an upper level, use a back button.
trans-unit.target: For other types of backwards navigation or navigation to an upper level, use a back button.

trans-unit.source: Example
trans-unit.target: Example

trans-unit.source: This example uses two buttons, Close all and Cancel, in a dialog in the Microsoft Edge browser.
trans-unit.target: This example uses two buttons, Close all and Cancel, in a dialog in the Microsoft Edge browser.

trans-unit.source: Example of buttons, used in a dialog
trans-unit.target: Example of buttons, used in a dialog

trans-unit.source: Create a button
trans-unit.target: Create a button

trans-unit.source: This example shows a button that responds to a click.
trans-unit.target: This example shows a button that responds to a click.

trans-unit.source: Create the button in XAML.
trans-unit.target: Create the button in XAML.

trans-unit.source: Or create the button in code.
trans-unit.target: Or create the button in code.

trans-unit.source: Handle the Click event.
trans-unit.target: Handle the Click event.

trans-unit.source: Button interaction
trans-unit.target: Button interaction

trans-unit.source: When you tap a Button with a finger or stylus, or press a left mouse button while the pointer is over it, the button raises the [**Click**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.buttonbase.click.aspx) event.
trans-unit.target: When you tap a Button with a finger or stylus, or press a left mouse button while the pointer is over it, the button raises the [**Click**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.buttonbase.click.aspx) event.

trans-unit.source: If a button has keyboard focus, pressing the Enter key or the Spacebar key also raises the Click event.
trans-unit.target: If a button has keyboard focus, pressing the Enter key or the Spacebar key also raises the Click event.

trans-unit.source: You generally can't handle low-level [**PointerPressed**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.uielement.pointerpressed.aspx) events on a Button because it has the Click behavior instead.
trans-unit.target: You generally can't handle low-level [**PointerPressed**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.uielement.pointerpressed.aspx) events on a Button because it has the Click behavior instead.

trans-unit.source: For more info, see [Events and routed events overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/mt185584.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more info, see [Events and routed events overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/mt185584.aspx).

trans-unit.source: You can change how a button raises the Click event by changing the [**ClickMode**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.buttonbase.clickmode.aspx) property.
trans-unit.target: You can change how a button raises the Click event by changing the [**ClickMode**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.buttonbase.clickmode.aspx) property.

trans-unit.source: The default ClickMode value is **Release**.
trans-unit.target: The default ClickMode value is **Release**.

trans-unit.source: If ClickMode is **Hover**, the Click event can't be raised with the keyboard or touch.
trans-unit.target: If ClickMode is **Hover**, the Click event can't be raised with the keyboard or touch.

trans-unit.source: Button content
trans-unit.target: Button content

trans-unit.source: Button is a [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/windows.ui.xaml.controls.contentcontrol.aspx).
trans-unit.target: Button is a [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/windows.ui.xaml.controls.contentcontrol.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Its XAML content property is [**Content**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/windows.ui.xaml.controls.contentcontrol.content.aspx), which enables a syntax like this for XAML: `<Button>A button's content</Button>`.
trans-unit.target: Its XAML content property is [**Content**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/windows.ui.xaml.controls.contentcontrol.content.aspx), which enables a syntax like this for XAML: `<Button>A button's content</Button>`.

trans-unit.source: You can set any object as the button's content.
trans-unit.target: You can set any object as the button's content.

trans-unit.source: If the content is a [UIElement](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/windows.ui.xaml.uielement.aspx), it is rendered in the button.
trans-unit.target: If the content is a [UIElement](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/windows.ui.xaml.uielement.aspx), it is rendered in the button.

trans-unit.source: If the content is another type of object, its string representation is shown in the button.
trans-unit.target: If the content is another type of object, its string representation is shown in the button.

trans-unit.source: Here, a **StackPanel** that contains an image of a banana and text is set as the content of a button.
trans-unit.target: Here, a **StackPanel** that contains an image of a banana and text is set as the content of a button.

trans-unit.source: The button looks like this.
trans-unit.target: The button looks like this.

trans-unit.source: A button with image and text content
trans-unit.target: A button with image and text content

trans-unit.source: Create a repeat button
trans-unit.target: Create a repeat button

trans-unit.source: A [**RepeatButton**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.repeatbutton.aspx) is a button that raises [**Click**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.buttonbase.click.aspx) events repeatedly from the time it's pressed until it's released.
trans-unit.target: A [**RepeatButton**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.repeatbutton.aspx) is a button that raises [**Click**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.buttonbase.click.aspx) events repeatedly from the time it's pressed until it's released.

trans-unit.source: Set the [**Delay**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.repeatbutton.delay.aspx) property to specify the time that the RepeatButton waits after it is pressed before it starts repeating the click action.
trans-unit.target: Set the [**Delay**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.repeatbutton.delay.aspx) property to specify the time that the RepeatButton waits after it is pressed before it starts repeating the click action.

trans-unit.source: Set the [**Interval**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.repeatbutton.interval.aspx) property to specify the time between repetitions of the click action.
trans-unit.target: Set the [**Interval**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.controls.primitives.repeatbutton.interval.aspx) property to specify the time between repetitions of the click action.

trans-unit.source: Times for both properties are specified in milliseconds.
trans-unit.target: Times for both properties are specified in milliseconds.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows two RepeatButton controls whose respective Click events are used to increase and decrease the value shown in a text block.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows two RepeatButton controls whose respective Click events are used to increase and decrease the value shown in a text block.

trans-unit.source: Recommendations
trans-unit.target: Recommendations

trans-unit.source: Make sure the purpose and state of a button are clear to the user.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the purpose and state of a button are clear to the user.

trans-unit.source: Use a concise, specific, self-explanatory text that clearly describes the action that the button performs.
trans-unit.target: Use a concise, specific, self-explanatory text that clearly describes the action that the button performs.

trans-unit.source: Usually button text content is a single word, a verb.
trans-unit.target: Usually button text content is a single word, a verb.

trans-unit.source: If the button's text content is dynamic, for example, it is localized, consider how the button will resize and what will happen to controls around it.
trans-unit.target: If the button's text content is dynamic, for example, it is localized, consider how the button will resize and what will happen to controls around it.

trans-unit.source: For command buttons with text content, use a minimum button width.
trans-unit.target: For command buttons with text content, use a minimum button width.

trans-unit.source: Avoid narrow, short, or tall command buttons with text content.
trans-unit.target: Avoid narrow, short, or tall command buttons with text content.

trans-unit.source: Use the default font unless your brand guidelines tell you to use something different.
trans-unit.target: Use the default font unless your brand guidelines tell you to use something different.

trans-unit.source: For an action that needs to be available across multiple pages within your app, instead of duplicating a button on multiple pages, consider using a [bottom app bar](app-bars.md).
trans-unit.target: For an action that needs to be available across multiple pages within your app, instead of duplicating a button on multiple pages, consider using a [bottom app bar](app-bars.md).

trans-unit.source: Expose only one or two buttons to the user at a time, for example, Accept and Cancel.
trans-unit.target: Expose only one or two buttons to the user at a time, for example, Accept and Cancel.

trans-unit.source: If you need to expose more actions to the user, consider using [checkboxes](checkbox.md) or [radio buttons](radio-button.md) from which the user can select actions, with a single command button to trigger those actions.
trans-unit.target: If you need to expose more actions to the user, consider using [checkboxes](checkbox.md) or [radio buttons](radio-button.md) from which the user can select actions, with a single command button to trigger those actions.

trans-unit.source: Use the default command button to indicate the most common or recommended action.
trans-unit.target: Use the default command button to indicate the most common or recommended action.

trans-unit.source: Consider customizing your buttons.
trans-unit.target: Consider customizing your buttons.

trans-unit.source: A button's shape is rectangular by default, but you can customize the visuals that make up the button's appearance.
trans-unit.target: A button's shape is rectangular by default, but you can customize the visuals that make up the button's appearance.

trans-unit.source: A button's content is usually text—for example, Accept or Cancel—but you could replace the text with an icon, or use an icon plus text.
trans-unit.target: A button's content is usually text—for example, Accept or Cancel—but you could replace the text with an icon, or use an icon plus text.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that as the user interacts with a button, the button changes state and appearance to provide feedback to the user.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that as the user interacts with a button, the button changes state and appearance to provide feedback to the user.

trans-unit.source: Normal, pressed, and disabled are examples of button states.
trans-unit.target: Normal, pressed, and disabled are examples of button states.

trans-unit.source: Trigger the button's action when the user taps or presses the button.
trans-unit.target: Trigger the button's action when the user taps or presses the button.

trans-unit.source: Usually the action is triggered when the user releases the button, but you also can set a button's action to trigger when a finger first presses it.
trans-unit.target: Usually the action is triggered when the user releases the button, but you also can set a button's action to trigger when a finger first presses it.

trans-unit.source: Don't use a command button to set state.
trans-unit.target: Don't use a command button to set state.

trans-unit.source: Don't change button text while the app is running; for example, don't change the text of a button that says "Next" to "Continue".
trans-unit.target: Don't change button text while the app is running; for example, don't change the text of a button that says "Next" to "Continue".

trans-unit.source: Don't swap the default submit, reset, and button styles.
trans-unit.target: Don't swap the default submit, reset, and button styles.

trans-unit.source: Don't put too much content inside a button.
trans-unit.target: Don't put too much content inside a button.

trans-unit.source: Make the content concise and easy to understand (nothing more than a picture and some text).
trans-unit.target: Make the content concise and easy to understand (nothing more than a picture and some text).

trans-unit.source: Back buttons
trans-unit.target: Back buttons

trans-unit.source: The back button is a system-provided UI affordance that enables backward navigation through either the back stack or navigation history of the user.
trans-unit.target: The back button is a system-provided UI affordance that enables backward navigation through either the back stack or navigation history of the user.

trans-unit.source: The scope of the navigation history (whether in-app or global) depends on the device and device mode.
trans-unit.target: The scope of the navigation history (whether in-app or global) depends on the device and device mode.

trans-unit.source: Example
trans-unit.target: Example

trans-unit.source: The UI for the system back button is optimized for each device and input type, but the navigation experience is global and consistent across devices and Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
trans-unit.target: The UI for the system back button is optimized for each device and input type, but the navigation experience is global and consistent across devices and Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

trans-unit.source: These different experiences include:
trans-unit.target: These different experiences include:

trans-unit.source: Devices Phone ![system back on a phone
trans-unit.target: Devices Phone ![system back on a phone

trans-unit.source: Always present.
trans-unit.target: Always present.

trans-unit.source: A software or hardware button at the bottom of the device.
trans-unit.target: A software or hardware button at the bottom of the device.

trans-unit.source: Global back navigation within the app and between apps.
trans-unit.target: Global back navigation within the app and between apps.

trans-unit.source: Tablet ![system back on a tablet (in tablet mode)
trans-unit.target: Tablet ![system back on a tablet (in tablet mode)

trans-unit.source: Always present in Tablet mode.
trans-unit.target: Always present in Tablet mode.

trans-unit.source: Not available in Desktop mode.
trans-unit.target: Not available in Desktop mode.

trans-unit.source: Title bar back button can be enabled, instead.
trans-unit.target: Title bar back button can be enabled, instead.

trans-unit.source: See [PC, Laptop, Tablet](#PC).
trans-unit.target: See [PC, Laptop, Tablet](#PC).

trans-unit.source: Users can switch between running in Tablet mode and Desktop mode by going to **Settings > System > Tablet mode** and setting **Make Windows more touch-friendly when using your device as a tablet**.
trans-unit.target: Users can switch between running in Tablet mode and Desktop mode by going to **Settings > System > Tablet mode** and setting **Make Windows more touch-friendly when using your device as a tablet**.

trans-unit.source: A software button in the navigation bar at the bottom of the device.
trans-unit.target: A software button in the navigation bar at the bottom of the device.

trans-unit.source: Global back navigation within the app and between apps.
trans-unit.target: Global back navigation within the app and between apps.

trans-unit.source: PC, Laptop, Tablet ![system back on a pc or laptop
trans-unit.target: PC, Laptop, Tablet ![system back on a pc or laptop

trans-unit.source: Optional in Desktop mode.
trans-unit.target: Optional in Desktop mode.

trans-unit.source: Not available in Tablet mode.
trans-unit.target: Not available in Tablet mode.

trans-unit.source: See [Tablet](#Tablet).
trans-unit.target: See [Tablet](#Tablet).

trans-unit.source: Disabled by default.
trans-unit.target: Disabled by default.

trans-unit.source: Must opt in to enable it.
trans-unit.target: Must opt in to enable it.

trans-unit.source: Users can switch between running in Tablet mode and Desktop mode by going to **Settings > System > Tablet mode** and setting **Make Windows more touch-friendly when using your device as a tablet**.
trans-unit.target: Users can switch between running in Tablet mode and Desktop mode by going to **Settings > System > Tablet mode** and setting **Make Windows more touch-friendly when using your device as a tablet**.

trans-unit.source: A software button in the title bar of the app.
trans-unit.target: A software button in the title bar of the app.

trans-unit.source: Back navigation within the app only.
trans-unit.target: Back navigation within the app only.

trans-unit.source: Does not support app-to-app navigation.
trans-unit.target: Does not support app-to-app navigation.

trans-unit.source: Surface Hub ![system back on a surface hub
trans-unit.target: Surface Hub ![system back on a surface hub

trans-unit.source: Always present.
trans-unit.target: Always present.

trans-unit.source: A software button at the bottom of the device.
trans-unit.target: A software button at the bottom of the device.

trans-unit.source: Back navigation within the app and between apps.
trans-unit.target: Back navigation within the app and between apps.

trans-unit.source: Recommendations
trans-unit.target: Recommendations

trans-unit.source: Enable back navigation.
trans-unit.target: Enable back navigation.

trans-unit.source: If back navigation is not enabled, your app is included on the global back stack, but in-app page navigation history is not maintained.
trans-unit.target: If back navigation is not enabled, your app is included on the global back stack, but in-app page navigation history is not maintained.

trans-unit.source: Enable the title bar back button in Desktop mode.
trans-unit.target: Enable the title bar back button in Desktop mode.

trans-unit.source: In-app page navigation history is maintained, app-to-app back navigation is not supported.
trans-unit.target: In-app page navigation history is maintained, app-to-app back navigation is not supported.

trans-unit.source: **Note** In Tablet mode, the title bar is displayed when a user swipes down from the top of the device or moves a mouse pointer near the top of the device.
trans-unit.target: **Note** In Tablet mode, the title bar is displayed when a user swipes down from the top of the device or moves a mouse pointer near the top of the device.

trans-unit.source: To avoid duplication and confusion, the title bar back button is not displayed in Tablet mode.
trans-unit.target: To avoid duplication and confusion, the title bar back button is not displayed in Tablet mode.

trans-unit.source: Hide or disable the title bar back button in Desktop mode when in-app navigation history is depleted or unavailable.
trans-unit.target: Hide or disable the title bar back button in Desktop mode when in-app navigation history is depleted or unavailable.

trans-unit.source: Provides a clear indication to the user that they have navigated back as far as possible.
trans-unit.target: Provides a clear indication to the user that they have navigated back as far as possible.

trans-unit.source: Each back command should go back one page in the back stack, or, if not in Desktop mode, to the immediately preceding app.
trans-unit.target: Each back command should go back one page in the back stack, or, if not in Desktop mode, to the immediately preceding app.

trans-unit.source: Users could get confused if back navigation is not intuitive, consistent, and predictable.
trans-unit.target: Users could get confused if back navigation is not intuitive, consistent, and predictable.
